headline: Salesforce (CRM) Expands AI-Driven Customer Experiences Through Deeper NiCE Collaboration
summary: Salesforce (CRM) took a 6% dip in its share price last week amidst a backdrop of positive market trends, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq hitting record highs. While the company announced an expanded partnership with NiCE to integrate AI-driven services into its Service Cloud, this development seemed at odds with the broader market momentum and didn't provide enough uplift to counteract the decline. headline: Saudi Arabia Cloud Computing Market Outlook and Company Analysis Report 2025-2033 Featuring Google, AWS,  Alibaba, Microsoft, Oracle, CloudSigma, VMware, Salesforce, Saudi Telecom Co, IBM
summary: The Saudi Arabia Cloud Computing Market is set for significant growth, with a projected CAGR of 11.33% from 2025 to 2033, reaching US$ 38.23 billion by 2033, up from US$ 14.55 billion in 2024. This expansion is driven by digital transformation, increased enterprise cloud adoption, and government initiatives under Vision 2030 aimed at modernizing IT infrastructure and fostering innovation. headline: Copado Launches Org Intelligence to Provide End-to-End Visibility into Salesforce Environments
summary: Copado, the leader in AI-powered DevOps for business applications, today announced the launch of Org Intelligence, helping organizations discover, develop, and deploy Salesforce changes. Copado's Org Intelligence enables faster, more accurate decisions, generates org-ready code, and streamlines issue resolution – ensuring smoother, safer releases.

headline: AcuityMD Makes the Forbes’ 2025 "Next Billion-Dollar Startups" List
summary: BOSTON, August 13, 2025--AcuityMD, the MedTech Intelligence Platform, has been named to Forbes’ 2025 "Next Billion-Dollar Startups" list – an elite group of 25 venture-backed U.S. companies identified as most likely to reach a $1 billion valuation. The list has a strong track record: more than 100 startups named in the past 10 years have since become unicorns.

headline: How the unraveling of two Pentagon projects may result in a costly do-over
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Donald Trump's Navy and Air Force are poised to cancel two nearly complete software projects that took 12 years and well over $800 million combined to develop, work initially aimed at overhauling antiquated human resources systems.  The reason for the unusual move: officials at those departments, who have so far put the existing projects on hold, want other firms, including Salesforce and billionaire Peter Thiel's Palantir, to have a chance to win similar projects, which could amount to a costly do-over, according to seven sources familiar with the matter.  Trump took office vowing to rid the government of what he calls waste and abuse.
